snippet: Every VW plant in the world has a works council that gives labor a voice at the management table. But selling the idea at its plant in Tennessee has been tough.
abstract: Volkswagon, facing intense pressure from United Automobile Workers to organize its plant in Tennessee, is expected to push for German-style works council as compromise; such councils, common in Europe, are composed of hourly and salaried employees that give labor a voice at management table, though they lack the negotiating and striking capacity of American unions.

byline.original: By JACK EWING and BILL VLASIC
byline.contributor: Jack Ewing reported from Frankfurt and Bill Vlasic from Detroit. Steven Greenhouse contributed reporting from New York.

lead_paragraph: Every VW plant in the world has a works council that gives labor a voice at the management table. But selling the idea at its plant in Tennessee has been tough.

headline.main: VW Plant Opens Door to Union and Dispute
headline.print_headline: VW Plant Opens Door To Union And Dispute
